title: Research unit ‘Rehabilitation & Learning’: the Re-Learn Lab
text:
Our lab is doing research in field of rehabilitation and acquisition of motor skills.
We investigate and design rehabilitation assessments and interventions in various settings. A focus is on the rehabilitation of older people and people with neurological disorders.
A special focus of our research unit are systematic reviews in different rehabilitation settings.
This website provides information on the Re-Learn Team and details of ongoing projects.
Should you be a student seeking a potential topic for a Bachelor’s or Master’s thesis, we would be pleased to hear from you.

title: Project Shade
text:
During hospitalisation, older adults are at risk of developing functional decline unrelated to the condition for which they were admitted. The loss of independence in at least one activity of daily living is referred to as hospital-associated disability (HAD). According to current reports, the incidence of HAD is 37% (Giacomino et al. 2023). Different interventions are proposed to prevent HAD (such as physical exercises), but it is often difficult to apply the results obtained in the studies into practice. These studies usually only specify the type of training to be done, such as strength training, without specifying any specific exercises or progression options. The objective is to evaluate the effectiveness of physical interventions in patients who are hospitalised or in a rehabilitation setting because of HAD and to develop a targeted training programme.
The SHADE project is divided into four work packages (WPs). In WP 1, we will perform a living systematic review with network meta-analysis, which evaluates the effectiveness of physical interventions that target HAD in older adults in the hospital or rehabilitation setting. WP 2 will aim to develop a system to organise and semi-automate the steps of the living systematic review. WP 3 will aim to validate a training programme and a clinical guideline with the highest current level of effectiveness based on the results of WP 1 and WP 2 with experts. WP 4 will aim to develop a web-based interactive platform for clinicians and patients that will include several components such as the updated results of the systematic review, a presentation of the guidelines of the exercise programme for clinicians, and a ready-to-use exercise programme for patients.
Clinicians will be able to keep up to date with new evidence in the field of HAD prevention. The results of this study are highly relevant to practice as those physical interventions preventing HAD are expected to decrease health costs and improve patient outcomes in the hospital phase. Furthermore, these results may potentially reduce the number of re-hospitalisations or costs related to home care.
The SHADE project is funded by the SNSF funding scheme “Health and wellbeing”.

title: K. Martin Sattelmayer
text:
Dr Martin Sattelmayer has been an associate professor at the School of Health Sciences at the HES-SO Valais-Wallis since 2016. He completed his physiotherapy training in the Netherlands with a Bachelor in Physiotherapy in 2003 (Zuyd University of Applied Sciences, Heerlen, NL). He has professional experience working as a physiotherapist in various clinical settings with a focus on neurological rehabilitation. Also, in 2005 he has obtained a Master’s degree in Neurological Rehabilitation from the Vrije Universiteit Brussel (Brussels, BE).
Martin teaches undergraduate physiotherapy students. His teaching activities mainly include modules in neurological rehabilitation and research methods modules. In 2010, he has expanded his teaching skills by obtaining a Master in Adult Education degree (Technische Universität Kaiserslautern, Kaiserslautern, GER).
In 2019, Martin has obtained a doctorate in Rehabilitation Sciences from Queen Margaret University in Edinburgh under the supervision of Dr Gillian Baer. As part of his doctorate studies, he investigated how to apply motor learning principles to improve the acquisition of procedural skills in physiotherapy education.
Martin´s research interests include the application of motor learning principles in the field of health professions education, the evaluation of complex health professions interventions and design and evaluation of assessments for procedural skills in educational and clinical settings.

title: Katia Giacomino
text:
Katia Giacomino obtained her Bachelor of Science degree in Physiotherapy in 2012 at the University of Applied Sciences Western Switzerland Valais-Wallis. For 3 years, she has worked at the neurology unit (acute and rehabilitation) of the Valais Hospital in Sierre and Sion. In 2015, she has expanded her professional activity to the University Hospital of Lausanne. At the same time, she worked towards completing her Master of Science degree in physiotherapy at the Department of Health Professions of Bern University of Applied Sciences. During her Master’s degree, she specialised in cardio-respiratory physiotherapy.
Since 2018, she is working as a scientific collaborator at the University of Applied Sciences Western Switzerland Valais-Wallis in Leukerbad. There, she is involved in various research projects and is conducting research for her PhD project. She is completing her PhD project in a collaboration between Prof. Martin Karl Sattelmayer from HES-SO Valais-Wallis, Prof. Jan Taeymans from the Department of Health Professions of the University of Applied Sciences in Bern and Prof David Beckwée from the Department of Physiotherapy of the Vrije Universiteit in Brussels.  The aim of one of the studies as part of her PhD project was to identify the tools used to assess activities of daily living in older people and to measure the incidence of hospital-associated disability in the hospital setting. Her current doctoral study focuses on improving the method of assessing patients’ performance in activities of daily living.
She is currently also continuing her professional activities, working at the Geriatric and Neurologic department of the Valais Hospital in Sierre.
